comments.author: Lydia Powers

top_comment.text:
While I know that the use of "baby sister" throughout is symbolic of the 
way Lizzie and Jane view Lydia, it really bothers me. She's not that much 
younger, I've never met people who call their siblings that constantly.﻿
top_comment.author: queenfinch

comments.text:
Remember that siblings' ways of thinking about each other are largely 
established they're still very young, when even a relatively small gap can 
seem much larger. This can then be amplified by the different social roles 
that are often assigned first-born, youngest, etc...
comments.author: Miles Bader

comments.text:
Lizzie is 24 almost 25 here and Lydia has just turned 21, so that's a 3-4 
year age gap. When Lizzie was graduating high school, Lydia was just 
starting, so I feel like that's a pretty significant age gap. Maybe that's 
just me, since my sister and I are pretty much the same age though.
comments.author: Cassidy Parker Knight

comments.text:
It depends on the person and the family, definitely.

And you hit the nail on the head, right, you said that it bothers you, and 
it should, because the whole "baby sister" view was kind of a root cause. 
It is problematic, and they do learn to grow past it. Just not yet.
comments.author: elwynbrooks

comments.text:
+waitingforluke I'm the second of six siblings, and the youngest is 15 
years younger than I am, but I still don't call him my "baby brother". I 
guess it depends on the family.
comments.author: queenfinch

comments.text:
I'm the second of four girls and my youngest sister is the youngest by 
almost five years. She is always referred to as the baby sister and "Baby" 
is one of her nicknames. It may be a little more common than you think. :)
comments.author: waitingforluke

comments.text:
My brother and I have about the same age gap as Lizzie and Lydia, and he's 
also the youngest, and I call him my baby brother all the time. Just for 
some perspective :)
comments.author: Sarah Shay

comments.author: NoriMori

captions.text: Lizzie: Welcome to the den!
Yay! New room.
So, why am I here? While I was gone, Mom decided to take up meditating.
Yes, you heard me right. Meditating.
Don't get me wrong, I am all for her trying to find some sort of inner peace.
I think we all are.
But guess which daughter's room got turned into her new sanctuary? Yup.
It's difficult not to take this as a not-so-subtle hint to move out and move on.
FYI, Jane's room is now  a sewing  room. My bed is still there but my books and
desk are gone, replaced by an aquarium full of tropical fish and seahorses.
Because that's tranquil? But here I am, in the den.
Of all the rooms in the house I figured it had the
best view of the hallway to the stairs, so at least...
My name is Lizzie Bennet and if you think I'm distracting myself until Lydia shows up, you're right.

"Consequences"
Written by Rachel Kiley
Lizzie: So Lydia isn't answering my calls or texts.
And she hasn't been home all day. Mom and Dad are out, but they don't know where she is either.
All Mom said was...
She's been spending a lot of time with that lovely swimmer lately.
Hopefully soon they'll be making tiny swimmers of their own.
I wish I was kidding. But at least it's obvious Mom and Dad don't know.
Jane's swamped getting ready for fashion week.
I have no idea if she's been talking to Lydia, but
I'm going to assume the fact that I haven't received any frantic phone calls from
her means that she doesn't know. And if Jane doesn't know, and Mom and Dad don't know,
it means there's a chance I can talk to Lydia and get her to take the site down
before things get any more out of hand. I can't believe this is happening.
This is my little sister.
My baby sister.
I can still remember her asking me to help her pick out an outfit for her very first date.
She was excited but nervous, so nervous.
And now she's...
I don't even know.
I don't know how George talked her into this.
I tried to watch some of the videos she made with him and honestly?
I couldn't get through one.
Let's face it, George has a history of convincing smart women to do dumb things.
I know how charming he can be, and that he's manipulating her.
Hopefully, I can convince her to stand up to him.
Should we have seen this coming?
Lydia (off-screen):  Just call me when you get a chance, okay?
I know you're busy, I just miss you.
Lizzie: Lydia?
Lydia (off-screen):  You're back.
Lizzie: Where've you been? I've been trying to call you all day.
Lydia: With Mary.
And in class, being responsible.
Lizzie: Can we talk?
Lydia: Not interested.
Lizzie: Please?
We haven't talked in weeks. I'll turn the camera off.
Lydia: No. Leave it on.
Anything you have to say me, you can say in front of everyone.
I mean, this is how we have most of our conversations now, right?
Lizzie: Fine, you want to put everything on the internet,
what's one stupid little conversation, right?
Lydia: God, you never stop, do you?
Lizzie: This isn't about me, this about you.
How on earth you could you possibly think this was a good idea?
Lydia: What are you talking about?
Lizzie: I know, okay?
I know about...George.
Lydia: What goes on between me and George is none of your business.
Lizzie: You're making it everyone's business.
Lydia: God! He said you wouldn't understand. Can't you just be happy for me, for once?
Lizzie: Have you lost your mind?
I know how persuasive he can be, but what were you thinking?
You know the internet is forever, right?
I mean, this is going to follow you for the rest of your life. You may not care now, but...
Lydia?
Lydia: This is a joke, right?
Lizzie: What?
Lydia: It's a joke. You or...George...
...somebody...
it's a joke.
Lizzie: You didn't know.
Oh my god.
Lydia: No, no, no. This is not real.
This is not happening.
He would never...
He loves me.
He loves me, this isn't--
I, um...
Lizzie: Lydia--
Lydia: I, uh...
No! No, no...
He said...
